title: 110_s2784
content: The Act may be cited as the Howard M. Metzenbaum "Menu Education and Labeling Act" or the "MEAL Act". Congress acknowledges the strong link between diet and health, with diet-related diseases starting early in life. Increased caloric intake is a key factor contributing to the rise in obesity rates in the United States. Obesity is associated with various health risks and has significant economic costs. The prevalence of meals prepared or eaten outside the home has increased over the past two decades, impacting overall caloric intake and food spending habits. Over the past 2 decades, there has been a significant increase in meals eaten outside the home, with a third of calories and half of food dollars spent on restaurant food. Excess saturated fat intake is a major risk factor for heart disease, leading cause of death in the US. Increased sodium intake is linked to high blood pressure, a risk for cardiovascular disease. The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act of 1990 requires food manufacturers to provide nutrition information on packaged foods, but restaurant foods are exempt unless a nutrient content or health claim is made. About 75% of adults use food labels on packaged foods, leading to healthier diets. Consumers find it challenging to limit calorie intake at restaurants due to limited nutrition information available. Consumers want nutrition information provided at restaurants to make educated decisions about their food choices and reduce obesity rates. SEC. 3. NUTRITION LABELING OF STANDARD MENU ITEMS AT CHAIN RESTAURANTS. Section 403(q)(5) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to require chain restaurants with 20 or more locations to disclose certain information about their food items. Chain restaurants with 20 or more locations must disclose calorie, fat, and sodium content of standard food servings on menus. Additional nutrition information must also be provided to help the public understand the significance of the data in the context of a daily diet. Chain restaurants with 20 or more locations are required to display calorie, fat, and sodium content on menus. Additional nutrition information must be provided to help the public understand the data in the context of a daily diet. Chain restaurants with 20 or more locations must provide written nutrition information upon request. Certain food items like condiments and daily specials are exempt from calorie labeling requirements. Self-service facilities must display calorie information per standard serving. Retail food establishments are not bound by these regulations. Retail food establishments, such as restaurants, can voluntarily provide additional nutrition information that complies with labeling requirements. States can also impose their own regulations for nutrition information beyond federal requirements. Proposed regulations must be implemented within one year of enactment. The Secretary must promulgate proposed regulations within 1 year and final regulations within 2 years to implement the clause on nutrition information for food establishments. Variations in serving sizes and food preparation factors must be considered in the regulations. The Secretary must promulgate final regulations within 2 years to implement the clause on nutrition information for food establishments, with provisions for vending machines. If the deadline is missed, proposed regulations will become effective as final regulations. The final regulations require vending machine operators with 20 or more machines to display calorie information on a sign near the food items. Operators can also provide additional nutrition information voluntarily. The regulations allow vending machine operators to voluntarily provide additional nutrition information, and states can also impose their own requirements for nutrition information. The Secretary must propose regulations within 1 year and finalize them within 2 years of enactment. The Secretary must propose regulations within 1 year and finalize them within 2 years of enactment. If final regulations are not issued within 2 years, the proposed regulations will become effective as final regulations.
